lecture_analysis.lecture_title: Integral (energy) method for thermal boundary layer and Nusselt number on a flat plate
lecture_analysis.lecture_summary: The lecture develops the integral energy approach to determine the thermal boundary-layer thickness and local convective heat transfer for laminar flow over a heated flat plate. Starting from mass and energy balances across a control volume inside the boundary layer, it shows how to assume simple velocity and temperature profiles, compute the convective energy flux, equate it to conductive surface heat flux, and obtain scaling relations between thermal and momentum boundary layers and the local Nusselt number. The procedure is applied for linear profile assumptions to produce the Prandtl- and Reynolds-number dependences of the thermal thickness and heat-transfer coefficient.
core_topics: Integral energy (momentum) method for boundary layers
Mass and energy balance in a boundary-layer control volume
Relation between thermal and momentum boundary layers
Local heat flux and surface heat transfer
Nusselt number scaling with Re and Pr
Use of Prandtl and Reynolds numbers in scaling laws
learning_objectives: Explain the integral energy balance approach for a boundary-layer control volume
Assume and use simple velocity and temperature profiles to evaluate convective energy flux
Compute the local heat flux at the surface from a temperature profile
Derive the relation between thermal and momentum boundary-layer thicknesses
Determine the scaling of the local Nusselt number with Reynolds and Prandtl numbers
Apply the integral method to obtain an approximate convective heat-transfer coefficient for a flat plate
assumed_prerequisites: Basic fluid mechanics and boundary-layer theory
Elementary heat transfer concepts (conduction, convection, Nusselt number)
Familiarity with nondimensional numbers: Reynolds and Prandtl

derivations.derivation_title: Integral-energy derivation of thermal boundary-layer thickness and Nu_x for laminar flow over a flat plate
derivations.derivation_stub: Show that $$\frac{\delta_T}{x} \sim \sqrt{12}\;\mathrm{Pr}^{-1/3} \mathrm{Re}_x^{-1/2}$$ and $$\mathrm{Nu}_x = \frac{h x}{k} \sim \frac{1}{\sqrt{12}}\mathrm{Pr}^{1/3} \mathrm{Re}_x^{1/2}$$ (using linear profiles and integral method).
steps: Set up integral energy balance on a control volume over 0\le y\le\delta_T: $$\dot{E}_{AB} - \dot{E}_{CD} - \dot{E}_{BC} + \dot{Q}=0.$$ Combine the terms to obtain the net convective energy change expressed as an excess over free-stream enthalpy, which leads to the compact expression (after algebra) for the rate of heat addition to the fluid from the surface: $$\dot{Q}=\rho c_p W \int_{0}^{\delta_T} u(y)\bigl(T(y)-T_\infty\bigr)\,dy.$$ (pages 1–2)
Define the distributed heat flux per unit width: $$\dot{q}(x)=\frac{1}{W}\frac{d\dot{Q}}{dx}\quad\text{(heat flux per unit plate length).}$$ (page 2)
Relate the surface heat flux to conduction at the wall: $$\dot{q}(x)= -k\left.\frac{dT}{dy}\right|_{y=0}.$$ (page 2)

Assume simple (closure) profiles for velocity and temperature in the boundary layers: linear velocity in the momentum boundary layer and linear thermal profile in the thermal boundary layer, i.e. $$u(y)=u_\infty\frac{y}{\delta},\qquad T(y)-T_\infty=(T_s-T_\infty)\Bigl(1-\frac{y}{\delta_T}\Bigr).$$ Introduce $$\beta\equiv\frac{\delta_T}{\delta}$$ and assume \(\beta\) constant (closure assumption). (pages 3–4)

Evaluate the integral for \(\dot{Q}\) using these profiles: substitute expressions into the integral $$\dot{Q}=\rho c_p W\int_0^{\delta_T} u(y)(T(y)-T_\infty)\,dy.$$ With the linear forms and \(\delta=\delta_T/\beta\) we get (change variable \(\xi=y/\delta_T\)): $$\int_0^{\delta_T}u(y)(T(y)-T_\infty)dy = u_\infty\beta (T_s-T_\infty)\delta_T\int_0^1 \xi(1-\xi)d\xi = u_\infty\beta (T_s-T_\infty)\delta_T\frac{1}{6}.$$ Thus $$\dot{Q}=\rho c_p W u_\infty\beta (T_s-T_\infty)\frac{\delta_T}{6}. $$ (pages 3–4)
Differentiate to get the local heat flux (per unit width): $$\dot{q}=\frac{1}{W}\frac{d\dot{Q}}{dx}=\rho c_p u_\infty\beta\frac{(T_s-T_\infty)}{6}\frac{d\delta_T}{dx}. $$ (page 4)

Equate the convective-derived flux to conductive flux at the wall: $$k\frac{(T_s-T_\infty)}{\delta_T}=\rho c_p u_\infty\beta\frac{(T_s-T_\infty)}{6}\frac{d\delta_T}{dx}. $$ Cancel \((T_s-T_\infty)\) to obtain an ODE for \(\delta_T(x)\): $$\frac{k}{\delta_T}=\rho c_p u_\infty\beta\frac{1}{6}\frac{d\delta_T}{dx}. $$ (page 4)

Rearrange and integrate: $$\delta_T\,d\delta_T = \frac{6k}{\rho c_p u_\infty\beta}dx\quad\Rightarrow\quad \frac{1}{2}\delta_T^2 = \frac{6k}{\rho c_p u_\infty\beta}x + C.$$ With zero thermal thickness at x=0 (C=0) get $$\boxed{\;\delta_T^2 = \frac{12\,k}{\rho c_p u_\infty\beta}\;x\;}.$$ Use \(\alpha=\dfrac{k}{\rho c_p}\) to write $$\delta_T^2 = \frac{12\,\alpha}{u_\infty\beta}\;x. $$ (pages 4–5)

Substitute \(\beta=\mathrm{Pr}^{-1/3}\) back into the \(\delta_T^2\) expression and express in terms of Reynolds and Prandtl numbers (use \(\mathrm{Re}_x=\dfrac{u_\infty x}{\nu}\)): $$\delta_T^2 = \frac{12\,\alpha}{u_\infty\beta}x = 12\frac{\alpha}{u_\infty x}\frac{x^2}{\beta}.$$ Hence $$\left(\frac{\delta_T}{x}\right)^2 = \frac{12}{\beta}\frac{\alpha}{u_\infty x}=\frac{12}{\beta}\frac{1}{\mathrm{Pr}\,\mathrm{Re}_x}.$$ Using \(\beta=\mathrm{Pr}^{-1/3}\) gives after algebra the scaling result $$\boxed{\;\frac{\delta_T}{x}=\sqrt{12}\;\mathrm{Pr}^{-1/3}\mathrm{Re}_x^{-1/2}\;}. $$ (pages 5–6)

Obtain the local Nusselt number using the linear-temperature relation (so local h = k/\delta_T): $$\mathrm{Nu}_x=\frac{h x}{k}=\frac{x}{\delta_T}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{12}}\mathrm{Pr}^{1/3}\mathrm{Re}_x^{1/2}.$$ Thus the integral method with linear profiles yields the classical scalings: $$\delta_T/x\propto\mathrm{Pr}^{-1/3}\mathrm{Re}_x^{-1/2},\qquad \mathrm{Nu}_x\propto\mathrm{Pr}^{1/3}\mathrm{Re}_x^{1/2}. $$ (pages 6–7)

Assumptions and completeness: The derivation is complete under the stated closure assumptions (linear velocity and temperature profiles; constant \(\beta\)). The result is an approximate integral solution — missing higher-order profile corrections and numerical prefactor sensitivity if non-linear profiles are used. (pages 1–7)

derivations.derivation_title: Integral expression for heat picked up by the boundary-layer (supporting)
derivations.derivation_stub: Derive the expression \(\dot{Q}=\rho c_p W\int_0^{\delta_T} u(y)(T(y)-T_\infty)\,dy\) and evaluate for linear profiles.
steps: From energy balance over the CV, the net heat gained by the fluid is the integral of convected enthalpy above free-stream: $$\dot{Q}=\rho c_p W\int_0^{\delta_T} u(y)\bigl(T(y)-T_\infty\bigr)\,dy.$$ (page 2)

For linear profiles, with \(u(y)=u_\infty y/\delta\) and \(T(y)-T_\infty=(T_s-T_\infty)(1-y/\delta_T)\) and \(\delta=\delta_T/\beta\), the integral evaluates to $$\int_0^{\delta_T}u(y)(T(y)-T_\infty)dy = u_\infty\beta (T_s-T_\infty)\delta_T\frac{1}{6},$$ giving $$\dot{Q}=\rho c_p W u_\infty\beta (T_s-T_\infty)\frac{\delta_T}{6}. $$ (pages 3–4)

derivations.derivation_title: Relation between thermal and momentum boundary-layer thicknesses (β relation)
derivations.derivation_stub: Show that \(\beta=\delta_T/\delta=\mathrm{Pr}^{-1/3}\) using integral results for \(\delta_T\) and \(\delta\).
steps: From integral energy result: $$\delta_T^2 = \frac{12\,\alpha}{u_\infty\beta}x.$$ From integral momentum (given) for the velocity boundary layer: $$\delta^2 = \frac{12\,\nu}{u_\infty}x.$$

conceptual_questions.question: For the laminar boundary-layer example with assumed linear velocity and temperature profiles, what is the relation between the thermal boundary-layer thickness δ_T and the velocity boundary-layer thickness δ in terms of the Prandtl number Pr?
conceptual_questions.explanation: Balancing the integral energy and momentum scalings in the lecture gives β = δ_T/δ with β^3 = α/ν = Pr^{-1}, so β = Pr^{-1/3}. Thus δ_T/δ ∝ Pr^{-1/3}.

conceptual_questions.question: Which two expressions are equated in the integral method procedure to obtain the local wall heat flux q̇ (and hence the differential equation for δ_T)?

options.text: q̇ = (1/W) dQ̇/dx (from the convected energy change) and q̇ = -k dT/dy |_{y=0} (Fourier heat flux at the wall).
q̇ = ρ cp u_∞ (T_s - T_∞) and q̇ = h (T_s - T_∞).
q̇ = ∫_0^{δ_T} ρ cp u(y) [T(y)-T_∞] dy and q̇ = k (T_s - T_∞).
q̇ = m_dot c_p T and q̇ = -k dT/dy |_{y=δ_T}.

conceptual_questions.explanation: The method computes the total convected heat into the control volume Q̇, differentiates to get heat flux per unit width q̇ = (1/W) dQ̇/dx, and equates that to the conductive flux at the wall q̇ = -k dT/dy|_{y=0} to solve for δ_T(x).

conceptual_questions.question: Using the example with linear u(y) and T(y) profiles, what is the local Nusselt number Nu_x dependence on Re_x and Pr (ignoring O(1) geometric constants)?

options.text: Nu_x = C Re_x^{1/2} Pr^{1/3} (with C = 1/√12 for the linear-profile example).
Nu_x is independent of Re_x and Pr.

conceptual_questions.explanation: From the derivation δ_T/x ∝ Pr^{-1/3} Re_x^{-1/2}, so h ≃ k/δ_T gives Nu_x = h x/k ∝ Re_x^{1/2} Pr^{1/3}. The lecture computes the prefactor for the linear-profile case as 1/√12.
